title: Blue Jays take on surging Hornets
text:
Blue Jays take on surging Hornets Bobby Ardoin, Special to the Daily World 5:05 p.m. CDT October 14, 2015 CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
What St. Edmund head coach Thomas David has seen on tape lately doesn’t contain anything deceptive. 
The Catholic High-Pointe Coupee team his Blue Jays face in New Roads on Thursday night is improving and that will cause St. Edmund problems when the teams meet in a District 5-1A contest at NRG Field. 
Catholic High started the year 0-3, but since then the Hornets (3-3, 1-0) have the program aimed in the right direction, said David. 
“I think just being under a new system earlier in the year, might have affected them, but they are playing better of late and they will be difficult to contain,” David said. 
The Hornets were outscored 133-62 in their losses. During the winning streak CHPC has played improved defense, allowing teams only a combined 57 points. 
David said the Jays have had some teachable defensive moments this week, learning the intricacies of the Hornets’ Flex-Bone style of offense. 
“You have to get your kids to realize this is going to be about playing assignment defense. They are doing a good job offensively at this point and their quarterback has been playing well and adapting to what they are trying to do. 
“It’s an offense where you have to play your assignments and you have to be responsible for the quarterback and the fullback. They are going to make big plays if each guy on defense doesn’t do his job,” David said. 
David said the Jays have seen similar versions of the Hornets’ offense , which is similar to Georgia Tech, so the recognition is not as difficult. 
St. Edmund (2-4, 1-0) ended a three-game losing streak last week with a 50-0 district victory over False River Academy. 
“We played a lot better overall. If we can eliminate the turnovers the rest of the way we are going to be all right,” said David. 
St. Edmund’s losses have come against Northwest High, Port Barre, Opelousas Catholic and Beau Chene, teams that are in higher classifications. 
The four schools that have defeated St. Edmund currently have 17-7 cumulative records. 
The Jays have thrown for 1,311 yards behind senior quarterback Drake Brunet. St. Edmund is averaging only 85.7 yards rushing per game. 
Brunet’s top targets have been running back Gibson Lafleur (47 receptions, 701 yards, 5 touchdowns), Cole Bergeron (26-144) and Will Chachere (13-206). 
Lafleur has rushed for 238 yards and a 5.9 yard-per-carry average. 
David said Lafleur’s performances this season haven’t surprised him. 
“He’s been an excellent ball player for us since he was a freshman. He’s a good overall athlete and a great football player,” said David. 
Like most of the Jays, Lafleur plays nearly the entire game. When he’s not running the football or catching Brunet’s passes, Lafleur is playing middle linebacker.
